hypothesis: I've been a national critic of film, music, photography, books and cultural issues in general. I've always preferred the term 'writer about . . .' to 'critic' or 'reviewer' (as in 'writer about movies or 'writer about dance'). A cultural subject - a live performance, a book, a painting, a film - is simply a complex occasion for writing well about something. A piece of 'criticism' is worthwhile not because of its particular opinion, but because it is entertaining, provocative, and illuminating not just of the particular work but of the work's place in a larger historical, artistic and social context. Ultimately, any 'critic' stands or falls on self-revelation: the subject under scrutiny is as much his or her particular prejudices, enthusiasms and acuity as the work under discussion. Professional critics are crucial to cultural vitality in many ways - as champions of unfamiliar works, as stimulators of curiosity, as goads to clearer, deeper thinking about an artistic experience, to name a few. Unlike the casual opinionators who crowd the Internet, the best professional critics become longtime companions - passionate, prickly friends with whom one can agree, laugh and argue over many shared experiences.

Finally, for hundreds of years, if not since antiquity, knowing more than one language was de rigueur for an educated and civilized person. One was not even considered educated without familiarity with at least one classical language and at least two modern ones. hypothesis: This discussion of tips is interesting but I want to put forward another reason why restaurant owners prefer a system of tipping over paying wages and building them into the price. A recent economic study showed that posting the price of a product in total, with sales tax included, impacted how much people bought of that product. So if we put a price of $4.79 on a product, people bought more than if the tag said $4.79   9% sales tax = $5.22. I mention this because economic theory says it shouldn't matter whether you advertise the whole price or not as consumers should be adding the tax in in their head when they make a decision. hypothesis: Conservatives often claim that taxing capital gains is double taxation. This is a fallacy and a myth. People and corporations are taxed only on their earnings. How is this any different than a person that invested the $50,000 into a business and then paid themselves a salary Likewise, with corporations, firms only pay taxes on their earnings. Corporations get to deduct all other expenses. So a person that owns a company could avoid the 'double taxation' issue by taking a salary instead of taking income in terms of profits. However, if most of the corporate profits were in the form of capital gains, then it may smarter to take the income as profits (two 15% tax rates results in an effective tax rate of 27.75%).

hypothesis: A lot of these comments criticize the use of RMP because students who don't like to do work and want to be entertained tend to like the easier professors. This is too shallow a view of RMP. RMP has extremely valuable information because people actually type in information. When you read over and over that the teacher fails to adequately explain material so that everyone is confused at test time, that's important information for a student. When you read again and again that the teacher doesn't like taking questions and instead prefers to stick to her outline, that's important information. When you read numerous reviews saying the students came away from the class with a new love of the material, that's important information. It's also really easy to see which professors are well-liked for being easy--which is also important information for a student who either needs a filler class to round out an otherwise brutal semester, or needs stronger instruction in that subject, in which case he can avoid the easy teacher. It's not about who has five stars versus one, there's much more to it than that.

hypothesis: This entire conversation gives me heartburn. I am a college teacher who, yes, has entries on Rate My Professor and who works for a college that overtly cites the website when lauding the success of its best teachers. So I pay attention to the public discussions of student evaluations. The heartburn comes not from fear that my rating index is too low but rather in the assumptions of both sides. The potential for abuse of these ratings is not based on students unqualified to evaluate their teachers (false, anyone can distinguish a poor product from a quality one) but rather on the methodology of Rate My Professor and other similar sites. As mentioned by at least one commenter, ratings suffer from selection bias and from a failure to use common terms. Those with strong opinions for or against are more likely to evaluate an instructor and what raters see as strict or smart or easy or dumb is so subjective that any two raters may have opposite definitions of the same word used in a rating. Not a good combination: an unrepresentative sample using uncommon terms to rate a product.

The other thing they could do, is team up with Community Colleges to formalize what a lot of poorer students are already doing: which is to go to community college for two years and then transfer into a state school. hypothesis: Conservatives often claim that taxing capital gains is double taxation. This is a fallacy and a myth. People and corporations are taxed only on their earnings. So if a person saved $50,000 and earned 5% interest, they would pay taxes only on the $2,500 in interest. The original $50,000 would remain untaxed. How is this any different than a person that invested the $50,000 into a business and then paid themselves a salary Likewise, with corporations, firms only pay taxes on their earnings. Corporations get to deduct all other expenses. So a person that owns a company could avoid the 'double taxation' issue by taking a salary instead of taking income in terms of profits. However, if most of the corporate profits were in the form of capital gains, then it may smarter to take the income as profits (two 15% tax rates results in an effective tax rate of 27.75%).

hypothesis: Growing up, I was always a high academic achiever. Still, I always asked my parents to proofread my work before turning it in. Those evenings in which my parents edited at my side turned out to improve my writing so much more than my teachers ever could. That one-on-one, painstakingly specific instruction taught me that active voice is preferable to passive and that there is a difference between formal, academic essays and casual, creative writing. Just because my parents helped me craft an essay didn't mean I didn't learn to become a better writer from that experience, and it certainly didn't make me dependent on them throughout my life. My younger sister, on the other hand, resisted their help, preferring to do her work alone. She became an exceptional writer and went to a great school. In the end, each kid has different needs. I don't think you can make a blanket statement saying 'all parents should do this' or 'all homework help (or homework, for that matter) is counterproductive.'

hypothesis: I'd like to know where Dr. Evins is getting her statistics. They contradict virtually everything I've read about marijuana, and they contradict my personal experience. I haven't smoked in since. These changes in usage had to do with availability and (mostly) social circumstances. (I didn't begin to crave it more; I gradually lost interest as the novelty wore off.) Marijuana in those days was very much a social drug; I smoked it alone just once in my life. I wouldn't even say that stopping and starting was easy; it was nothing whatsoever. I never encountered anyone at any time in my life who showed the slightest sign of being even slightly addicted. (I do know what addiction is. I've known many people, some of them close to me, clearly addicted to alcohol.) It's true, however, that marijuana does cause 'like memory and cognitive impairment'--TEMPORARILY. hypothesis: Codesharing seems to be the target of a lot of anti-trust ire, but no one talks about the good part of codesharing: simplifying and improving the travel experience for passengers with complex international travel needs. I occasionally find myself needing to fly from a small airport in the USA to even smaller airports in Europe. There are entire countries for which a direct flight from the US to any airport near your destination abroad simply don't exist. When I fly to Greece, for example, I usually need to take two or three different airlines to get there. If codesharing were not permitted, then each of those legs would have to be a separate ticket. Each would be one-way, and therefore ridiculously expensive. And if one leg of the itinerary was delayed so that I missed a flight, then it would be very difficult to get on a new flight. In fact, the next airline I have to deal with would have no obligation to rebook me at all! With codesharing, however, when I buy complex international itineraries I know that the price I'm charged will actually get me from point A to B, no matter how many connections I miss.

When I fly to Greece, for example, I usually need to take two or three different airlines to get there. If codesharing were not permitted, then each of those legs would have to be a separate ticket. Each would be one-way, and therefore ridiculously expensive. And if one leg of the itinerary was delayed so that I missed a flight, then it would be very difficult to get on a new flight. In fact, the next airline I have to deal with would have no obligation to rebook me at all! With codesharing, however, when I buy complex international itineraries I know that the price I'm charged will actually get me from point A to B, no matter how many connections I miss.

We hold on to these older designs out of sheer regulatory inertia, and we will continue to do so to our great environmental and proliferative detriment until voters demand that the NRC and its international counterparts create frameworks that encourage the development of commercial thorium-cycle power plants.

Crude oil from the Chesapeake to Iceland and a potentially mortal blow to already fragile shore communities and fisheries along the way. hypothesis: I've been a national critic of film, music, photography, books and cultural issues in general. I've always preferred the term 'writer about . . .' to 'critic' or 'reviewer' (as in 'writer about movies or 'writer about dance'). A cultural subject - a live performance, a book, a painting, a film - is simply a complex occasion for writing well about something. A piece of 'criticism' is worthwhile not because of its particular opinion, but because it is entertaining, provocative, and illuminating not just of the particular work but of the work's place in a larger historical, artistic and social context. Ultimately, any 'critic' stands or falls on self-revelation: the subject under scrutiny is as much his or her particular prejudices, enthusiasms and acuity as the work under discussion. Professional critics are crucial to cultural vitality in many ways - as champions of unfamiliar works, as stimulators of curiosity, as goads to clearer, deeper thinking about an artistic experience, to name a few. Unlike the casual opinionators who crowd the Internet, the best professional critics become longtime companions - passionate, prickly friends with whom one can agree, laugh and argue over many shared experiences.
